text:
The recommendation in
```Warning: `categorical!(df)` is deprecated. Use `transform!(df, names(df, Union{Missing, AbstractString}) .=> (x -> categorical(x, compress=false)), renamecols=false)` instead.```
is quite verbose. Is that really the new recommendation or is this one of the cases where the user should change workflow in a non-equivalent way?

elements.text: Warning: `categorical!(df)` is deprecated. Use `transform!(df, names(df, Union{Missing, AbstractString}) .=> (x -> categorical(x, compress=false)), renamecols=false)` instead.
is quite verbose. Is that really the new recommendation or is this one of the cases where the user should change workflow in a non-equivalent way?

text: In general this should be OK: `transform!(df, names(df) .=> categorical), renamecols=false)`.

elements.text: In general this should be OK:

text: It depends on whether you have non-string columns that you want to skip.

elements.text: It depends on whether you have non-string columns that you want to skip.

text: that does still seem like a quality-of-lief decrease

elements.text: that does still seem like a quality-of-lief decrease

text: We could improve the deprecation message but the message will have to be removed in 1.0 anyway because it adds a dependency on CategoricalArrays.

elements.text: We could improve the deprecation message but the message will have to be removed in 1.0 anyway because it adds a dependency on CategoricalArrays.

text: Yeah that's the typical case where there's a good replacement for most cases, but the 100% correct deprecation needs to be quite verbose.

elements.text: Yeah that's the typical case where there's a good replacement for most cases, but the 100% correct deprecation needs to be quite verbose.

text: Exactly, I think that was the origin of Andreas’ question

elements.text: Exactly, I think that was the origin of Andreas’ question
